Package me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.hardware.motor

Class MotorConfig

java.lang.Object
me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.hardware.motor.MotorConfig
public class MotorConfig
extends java.lang.Object
Configuration used for representing a motor's parameters.

After a motor configuration is created and passed to a motor, that motor will need to be controlled DIRECTLY, rather than through a configuration as a sort of proxy class.

Since:
0.1.0
Author:
Colin Robertson

  • Constructor Details

    • MotorConfig

      public MotorConfig​(Direction direction)
      Create a new MotorConfig - use default values for omitted parameters.
      Parameters:
      direction - the motor's direction.

    • MotorConfig

      public MotorConfig​(double min, double max, double multiplier, double deadzone, boolean isLazy, Direction direction)
      Create a new MotorConfig with a set of given options and parameters. Motors are intended to be highly tunable and customizable.

      To accommodate for the amount of customizable features that motors have, we need to use a special configuration class that makes passing values and parameters significantly easier. This class does exactly that.

      Parameters:
      min - the motor's minimum value. Any value below this value will be set to this value.
      max - the motor's maximum value. Any value above this value will be set to this value.
      multiplier - the motor's multiplier. All inputted power values are multiplied by this number, prior to clipping for min and max constraints. Any power value that you input will be multiplied by this, regardless of whether or not the output power value exceeds any limits that you've set up.
      deadzone - the motor's deadzone. Values that are within this range (distance from zero, positive direction) are considered to be "dead," meaning the motor isn't even spinning enough to move forwards. Deadzones help make motors live longer by only setting power when the applied power impacts the motor.
      isLazy - should the motor use lazy power? Lazy power setting is a potentially performance-enhancing feature of the Motor class that only sets power when needed. By not setting power, and by not calling more methods than have to be called, CPU cycles are saved. Saving CPU cycles helps to improve runtime performance and loop times significantly.
      direction - the motor's direction. A motor in the positive direction functions entirely normally and exactly as you'd expect it to. However, a motor in the negative direction functions entirely inverted. Setting power of 1 to a FORWARDS motor and -1 to a BACKWARDS motor will set exactly the same power.
